availability.p: All research and writing of Civil War Governors of Kentucky Digital Documentary Edition annotations was undertaken by project staff, volunteers, and interns. Each record contains citations to relevant primary and secondary source material. All annotations are copyright Kentucky Historical Society, and should be referenced as such in any published work.

seriesStmt.title: Civil War Governors of Kentucky Digital Documentary Edition

body.p: Lexington, Kentucky, doctor. Kentucky native. Married to Barbara G. Graves in Fayette County, Kentucky, on January 21, 1821. Father of Mary Elizabeth Chinn, Joseph Graves Chinn, William F. Chinn, Benjamin Graves Chinn, Penelope "Fanny" Chinn, Addison Ball Chinn, Anna Chinn, Hester Chinn, and Claudius Chinn. Married to second wife, Juretta W. Taylor, in 1850. Doctor in Lafayette County, Missouri, in 1850. Doctor in Lexington in 1860. Owned eight enslaved persons in 1860. Veteran of the War of 1812. Founding member of the Christian Church in Lexington.

ab.bibl:
Seventh Manuscript Census of the United States (1850), Population Schedules, Missouri, Lafayette County, District 46, p. 145B.
Eighth Manuscript Census of the United States (1860), Population Schedules, Kentucky, Fayette County, Lexington, p. 92.
Eighth Manuscript Census of the United States (1860), Slave Schedules, Kentucky, Fayette County, Lexington Ward 4, p. 52.
Find A Grave, "Dr Joseph Graves Chinn (1797-1891)," Memorial #26044662, http://www.findagrave.com/memorial/26044662 (accessed May 19, 2020).
War of 1812 Pension Application Files Index, 1812-1815, NARA RG 15, Microfilm Series M313, 102 rolls, Surname Range: Chi-Cla, Film #69.
J. Howard. Brown & Rossiter Johnson, The Twentieth Century Biographical Dictionary of Notable Americans, Vol II (Boston: The Biographical Society, 1904), p. 191.
